Name: SIMSOC
Description:
SIMSOC (pronounced sim'-sock), a unique social process game, was developed to make social science more vivid than has been possible with traditional teaching methods.  It is designed to be played WITHOUT the use of a computer.  SIMSOC is a way to actively involve students in processes of large-scale conflict, protest, social control, and social change.  SIMSOC creates a situation in which the participants must actively question the nature of social order.

Included are: Rules for playing, materials needed for play and questions to guide discussions afterward.  Materials are provided on perforated sheets and include: SimBucks of various denominations, travel passes, sustenance tickets, and coupons which can be exchanged for "munchies" during the game (representing luxuries).  Also included are play-aids, scenario leaflets and several puzzle sheets that are distributed to players as wage-earning jobs.

Players are citizens of a simulated modern international society taking on roles of political and industrial leaders, workers, the media, the judiciary and the unemployed.  Some randomly selected players may be "Minorities" (wearing masks or armbands) and can be victims of prejudice at any time by the other players.  Players attempt to deal with scenarios presented each session while attaining personal goals and maintaining a viable society.

SIMSOC is best with approximately 40 participants, and is intended to be played in 5 to 10 sessions of about an hour apiece.  Rules adjustments are included to support smaller groups and fewer, abbreviated sessions.  Space should be available to divide the players into 4 groups (or 3 for smaller games) preferably in separate rooms, although corners of a large room will suffice.

Name: Touring Scotland
Description:
An entirely new map game requiring skill and judgment.

Exciting, interesting, and educative.

A competitive game for 2-4 players in which the chief cities and towns are visited.

Object

Each player is dealt eight cards (two of each color).

The player arranges the cards, so as to form a journey by the shortest route, starting and finishing at the nearest large town to where the players live, or to where the game is being played.  Players then set off on their journeys. Along the way watch out for collisions, traffic lights, and ferries!

Corresponding numbers on the cards and towns to be visited are given, to enable very young children to easily identify their route.

The winner is the first person to have visited their eight towns and returned home.

Contents:

     1 playing board
     32 cards in 4 colors
     4 metal cars
     1 die
     1 wooden dice shaker
     rules

Name: Lari Safari
Description:
A fun childrens game that trains both the memory and their portraying skills.  Cards are face down, acting as a memory, when your turn, you have to portray the animals gesture drawn on the card(s). The drawings are very cute, and so are the kids acting them out..

Very simple game setup, lots of fun for smaller kids. or....

Also loads of fun on a late night with family or friends that had just a little to much to drink !

Name: My First Huisje Boompje Beestje
Description:
Pachisi for the smaller players that can't read or write yet.
All players move around the same board, so they may capture each others pawns. Captured pawns are returned to their player's corner and must start their journey over. The winner is the first player to move all pawns "home".

The numbers on the dice are replaced by 6 symbols: House, Animal, Tree, Tulip, Appel & Car.
Player gets to move his/her pawn forward to the indicated/thrown symbol.
Gameplay start after throwing a 'House'

Name: Pohjoisen Pikajunan Arvoitus
Description:
The board is map of Finland with not entirely accurate railway and bus network. One of the players is the mystery traveler who plans his/her route from on of three cities in southern Finland (Turku, Helsinki or Kouvola) to one of the three towns in northern Finland (Kolari, Rovaniemi or Keminjärvi) and back. He/she only reveals his/her whereabouts in every sixth city he/she visits.

If the mystery traveler can make his/her route, he/she is the winner. If any of the other players can get to the same city with the mystery traveler that player wins.

Players move by throwing dice and completing tasks in cities they visit. Mystery traveler doesn't throw dice.

This game is a promotional game from the Finnish transport company VR.

Name: Seafood Palace
Description:
Seafood Palace is a medium-weight resource management and auction game for three to five players aged 10 years and older. Games usually last from 60 to 90 minutes. The game features an innovative dice drafting mechanism for players to obtain resources used in bidding for cards which yield points. Each turn, players have a variety of actions available to them and tempo is an important consideration – it may be good to get a bid in first to win a card cheaply, but at the cost of taking a high value die instead.

In Seafood Palace, players take on the role of Chinese seafood restaurant owners in Singapore, seeking to gain fame points by bidding to satisfy public demand for tasty seafood dishes. The more resources you put into the dish, the more likely that people will identify that dish with your restaurant, and this recognition is represented by fame points.

Every player starts with stores of fish, prawn, crab, non-seafood resources (chicken and vegetable), beverages and coins. The resources are represented by counters on the player’s own board, which represents the player’s stores.

Each round, public demand is represented by dish cards that become available for auction. Players bid to satisfy the demand with the corresponding resources and the highest bid wins the card and the fame points on the card.

Each round, new resource dice and number dice are available for players to replenish stores.  These dice are traded in as pairs (one of each kind) to get the specified number of the specified type of resource (e.g. a 5-number die and a crab resource die are traded in for 5 crab resources).

There are also bonus cards which could permit special actions to benefit the player - some of the bonus action cards include discounts on buying seafood resources, using MSG to get an advantage over your competitors (but with a penalty) or the abundant catch that helps you stock up on seafood. Bonus cards could also be set menus, which if fulfilled by the end of the game, will yield bonus points. A wedding banquet menu is valuable, and this game also caters to vegetarians with a vegetarian set menu. If you hire a master chef, your lowly 1-point dishes will increase in value.

The twist is that players have to choose which of several actions they want to take (take a die, bid on a dish, claim a dish, bid on a bonus card, claim a bonus card, or pass) and focusing on one action means sacrificing the tempo to carry out another action. If you decide to go for the high number die, someone else could take the resource die of the type you need badly, and yet another will get in a bid on a valuable card that you can’t outbid because you haven’t managed to obtain the right dice yet …

The game lasts enough rounds so that each player has the advantage of going first an equal number of times. At the end of the game, players score fame points for dish cards they have won, set menus they have fulfilled with their dishes, and recognition for having the best stocked cellar (player with the most beverages) and best seafood stocks (player whose least seafood resource is greater than other players’ least seafood resource). The player with the most famous restaurant wins.

Seafood Palace was accepted for play-testing in the 2008 Hippodice competition

Name: Crazy Dice Math
Description:
A learning Math game from CB Publishing.

Includes:
2 Glow in the Dark 6 sided dice
1 Glow in the Dark 12 sided dice (special sides)
1 Instruction Book.

The book contains 10 games for 2 or more players.  Each game is a simple dice game to help with math skills.

Ages 7 and up.

Name: Moscow Defended
Description:
This is Moscow Attacked's smaller and simpler "little brother" (about the Battle of Moscow in late 1941)

Map scale: 100 kms per hex
Time scale: 1 turn = 20 days
Units: 14 ground and air units for the Germans and 16 for the Russians.

The game is available for FREE at http://LCoat.tripod.com/MoscDef.htm

Name: Santa Claus Takes the Intercity
Description:
A simple game of bidding for 25 intercity railway routes on a map of the Netherlands, self-published and sent to Han Heidema's gaming contacts as a Christmas gift in 1997.

Players needed to supply their own crayons or felt pens for colouring routes on the map, and each player needs a suit of 13 cards from a standard card deck.

Each turn, one card from a deck of 25 route cards is revealed. Players bid to win the route by each simultaneously playing a card from their hands. Highest untied card wins the route. The highest cards, winning cards, court cards and low cards (whose definition varies depending on number of players) are discarded after each bid. As each route is won it is coloured on the map to show its ownership, a la crayon rail games.

Each route is worth between 1 and 5 distance points. The winner is the player with the longest continuous route on the map when the 25 routes have all been won (or when all players are out of cards).

Simple but fun. The blue cardstock of the laminated map is the only downside, as it makes darker pen colours hard to differentiate.

Name: Matka Karjalaan
Description: Matka Karjalaan  (Journey to Karelia) is a slightly educational roll and move game. Players are dealt destination cards for cities in Karelia they have to visit. During the game they complete tasks in cities. Tasks are related to Karelian history and tradition. The game includes also chance cards that may send players to another city, or give them tasks similar to those appearing in cities. First player to visit all his destination cities and return is the winner.

Name: 101 Dalmatians: Spin for Spots
Description:
The puppies have lost their spots.  Help get them back!

Our playful puppies need their spots!  Spin the spinner to be the first to put all the spots back on your puppy!

For 2 to 4 players, Ages 3 and up.

Game Contents: 4 Stand-Up Puppy Playing Pieces With Cardboard Bases, Eight Plastic Assembly Stands For Cardboard Bases, Reusable Puppy Spots, Spinner, And Instructions.

Name: Hoe overleef ik mezelf spel
Description: A trivia cardgame around the books by Dutch author Francine Oomen in which the players learn a lot about themselves and each other. Some acting skills, a bit of courage and lots of humour are required to play the game.

Name: Het Hoe Overleef Ik: Spel
Description:
A boardgame themed around Dutch author Francine Oomen's books.

Each players gets 4 pawns in one colour. The players places the walls on the board on the spaces marked with a star. These walls block their way. The cards, with questions and instructions in 3 different categories, are placed next to the board.
Each turn, a player throws the die and can move in either direction, but only one direction each turn and only one pawn. When a player throws a 6, that player has an extra turn. A player can pass other pawns, but cannot pass the walls.
To remove a wall, a player has to land exactly on the space where the wall stands. Then another player draws a card and chooses a question or an instruction. If the player answers the question correctly or fulfills the assignment, the wall is removed and placed elsewhere on the board.
The player who finishes exactly with one of his/her pawns on the destination field, wins the game.

Name: In Your Face!
Description:
The object of In Your Face! is to get rid of all your cards before the other players do. Play the same color or number on the discard pile, or play Wild Cards. The game is played to an agreed upon score. The player with the fewest points at the end of the game is the winner.

When a player plays a wild card and tells you to draw a card, three cards, or lose a turn, if you have an IN YOUR FACE card you can play it and that player has to do what he/she told you to do, unless that player plays another IN YOUR FACE card, then you must draw or lose a turn.

Name: Nordopoly
Description: Nordopoly is yet another Monopoly clone. The game is a promotional item for Nordstrom department stores with squares and cards representing areas of the store such as Jewelry, Shoes, Sportswear, and Furnishings. The Jail Square is replaced with "Customer Service." Apparently, serving customers is equivalent to serving time.

Name: Quartette
Description:
Setup:
Alternate light and dark men on each of the back rows. Back rows will have 4 men each. Also the light and dark men will oppose each other across the board.  (See picture)

Movement:
Players alternate moving by moving one man one square either horizontally or vertically. Diagonal movement is not permitted.

Goal: 
To move your 4 men into a line either horizontally, vertically, or diagonally.

Equipment

     Rule sheet on dark red paper
     4 dark men, 4 light men
     4x4 grid gameboard with checkerboard coloring

Name: Krabbel, kleiner Käfer!
Description:
From the Box:

Four beetles have a funny race all over the country.  The coloured dice determines which of them can move, the number dice determines how far the journey goes each time.  Who's first to the sunflower?

Overview:

A simple little game that can be played with any child that knows how to count up to three, and can tell their colors.  Whoever moves a beetle to the sunflower gets to keep that beetle.  The person with the most beetles at the end of the game wins.

Content:

1 long game plan made from cardboard pieces, 4 wooden beetles in four colours, 1 coloured dice, 1 dice with number spots and game instructions.

Name: Tortoise vs. Hare
Description: A Print-and-Play Miniature War-game Based on the ever growing  conflict between the Tortoise and Hare Empires
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: The Tortoise and the Hare

Name: IceSickle
Description:
A single stash Icehouse game for two players.

Alternate turns placing pieces onto empty squares. Then take turns jumping a piece, diagonally or orthogonally, over at least one other piece into an empty square. Each piece can jump over its pip-count in squares. Remove the jumped pieces, and score their pips. Continue until no jumps remain.

Name: PFC: The Pro Football Chronology
Description:
Features:
All professional teams from the year 1920-2006 are included. (APFB, AFL & NFL)
Teams are rated in overall offense, defensive and execution ("X" factor, which is based on win percentage.) Teams are also assigned a power (P) rating, which fine-tunes a squad's offensive strength.
Fast and accurate results: Play a complete game in 5 to 10 minutes.
As in the high school game, the game engine is self-driven. You may still call for the 2-point conversion, run out the clock, attempt a 4th down conversion, use the hurry-up offense, and attempt onside kicks.
100 pre-printed action cards included, or you may use your own 10-sided dice or pre-printed random number sheets. (#'s 1-100)
Keep score and track the time expired as you play. Tally each team's cumulative plays and total yardage, if you wish to accumulate stats.

Name: Regional: The Game of Pro Bowling
Description:
Features:
All bowlers who competed in at least 3 rounds during the 2006 season are included
Non-PBA member bowlers also included
Optional lane condition system - May affect a bowlers final or individual frame score
2 ways to play: Quick mode or Ball-by-Ball; simulate an entire tournament quickly or watch the action unfold as it happens
Run your own regional tournaments; bowler charts are grouped by his or her home state

Name: Indulto: The Game of Bullfighting
Description:
Features:
The top 50 matadors of 2006 rated in every category
Large list of bulls, including weight & color. Bulls' behavior may lead to matador injuries.
63 of the world's top bull rings rated; the crowds play a part in the outcome
Fast action card driven; the matador performs the appropriate action for each tercio
Both matador and bull influence the action; a skilled matador will be awarded more trophies than those of inferior skill

Name: Friday Night: The Game of High School Football
Description:
Features:
All high school (and prep) football teams in each of the 50 states is included.
Teams are rated in overall offense, defensive and execution ("X" factor, which is based on win percentage.)
Quick playing: Play a complete game in 5 to 10 minutes.
Although most of the game engine is self-driven, there are a number of events which allow user decisions to influence the outcome: Go for the 2-point conversion, run out the clock, go for a 4th down conversion, conduct the hurry-up offense, and attempt the onside kick.
100 action cards included, or use your own dice/pre-printed random number sheets. (#'s 1-100)
Keep score and time expired as you play. Track each team's cumulative plays and total yardage.

Name: Trivial Pursuit: Chocolate Edition
Description: Trivial Pursuit - Chocolate Edition is a very simple implementation of the traditional Trivial Pursuit game. The game proceeds in turns taken in clockwise order. On your turn, the player to your right will ask you the questions. The question cards in this case are actually chocolate bites in paper wrap (on which the questions are written). The player who knows the answer to both questions on one card / bite gets it (and presumably digests it, as well). If an answer was wrong, the card is returned into the box. The player with the most correct answers in the end of the game is the winner, and is awarded the golden prize (which is made of chocolate, of course).

Name: Games of the Pilgrim's Progress, Going to Sunday School and Tower of Babel
Description:
An integrated three game set produced by McLoughlin Brothers, in true bookcase style. The wooden playing board has a pair of book-like spines on one side and the illusion of book pages on the others, with an outer slip case to hold everything together. The set also contains a dual arrowed spinning indicator which its makers proclaimed as "A Complete and Unobjectional Substitute for, and Improvement on Dice, Teetotums, &c."

In the basic Pilgrim's Progress game, played on the outer board halves, a player must move both of his pieces (two pawns: a Pilgrim and a Staff) by the number of spaces indicated by the dual spinner until he reaches the Giant Despair space. He then moves his Pilgrim alone until it lands by exact count on the Golden Gate, and thence (if not displaced) to victory in the Celestial City. Rules for three other variants are also included. These use various combinations of board spaces and require differing numbers of pieces.

In Going to Sunday School, played in one of the inner board halves, players spin and move around the board. Essentially, the player that lands on the most picture spaces (10 special spaces, each illustrating a virtue or a vice) is the winner.

The Tower of Babel, played in the other inner board half, combines a race for the top of the tower with a race to the bottom. Different rules apply to each race within the game. The winners of each half have a spin-off to determine the overall winner.

Contents:

     Rule booklet
     12 round-headed (Pilgrim) wood pawns
     6 pointed-headed (Staff) wood pawns
     Dual arrowed spinner
     Wooden game board
     Slip case

Name: Evel Knievel Stunt Game
Description:
"Evel Knievel races around the Track. You perform 6 Daredevil stunts. Most skillful cyclist wins."

A battery operated board game based on the exploits of the motorcycle riding, car jumping daredevil. The stunt motorcycle moves around a circular track and a "brake" button on the center motor allows the players to start and stop the motorcycle once a stunt has been set up. The six daredevil stunts the players perform are: Big Wheel (dodge the rolling tire), Barrel Barricade (stop before hitting the barrels), Wheelie, Stop on Ramp, Loop, and Pit Stop.

Components: Box, instructions, Evel Knievel cycle with wire, power pack, 2 barrels, 1 wheel ramp, 1 jump ramp, 1 incline, 1 wheel, and trophies. One D battery required.

Name: ONS.5: Outward North Atlantic Slow Convoy Five (1943)
Description:
This solitaire game depicts the struggle between Allied convoy ONS.5 and a large number of German U-boats in May 1943. This struggle is considered a turning point in the Battle of Atlantic.

The player tries to sink as many merchant ships as possible, the game system (rules and charts) governs the actions of the escort vessels.

Sequence of play (as taken from the rulebook):
Unit Availability Phase, Weather Phase, Convoy and Escort Movement Phase, U-boat Movement Phase, Search Phase, Combat Phase, Turn Record Phase

The game is available at http://www.kcl.ac.uk/schools/sspp/ws/consim.html

Name: Star Hopper
Description:
In this space-themed race game, you control 4 spaceships which you send out into the galaxy.  At random intervals, your home government approves colonization of various star systems, and the first starship there gets exclusive rights to colonize.  The first player with 4 colonies wins the game.

The star card deck show rough graphic representations and the actual names of the 40 closest star systems to our own, the next furthest out that we know or suspect might have planets, and other stars yet further out known for their place in constellations.  The rule book gives more details about each of the 107 star systems and general facts about astronomy and astrophysics.

Contains:  1 game board, 108 card deck, 6 six-colored six-sided dice, 24 colored spaceship pawns, 48 translucent colony marker chips, rule book

Name: Master Spy
Description:
In this fast-paced strategy and memory update of Battleship, you have been hired to manage 5 spies, which you deploy secretly (represented by pegs on a pegboard grid).  Every turn you move your spies hoping to encounter enemy spies based on intelligence gathered from your opponents.  The only random element is that each player rolls a die at the end of a turn, which may result in nothing happening, or in a few cases the retiring of one of their spies, the recruiting of a new spy, or their defection (all players trade their pegboards to the left) and a new set of spies to direct.

Contains:  4 pegboard trays, 16 terrain sheets, 240 colored pegs, 1 six-sided die, 4 peg cups (for captured spies), rules

Expansion trays will be available to accommodate up to 6 players.

Name: Samsara
Description: In this multi-player chess-like game, each player has 5 stackable follower pawns that start out along the edges of a wheel-shaped board.  Pawns become stronger by winning battles with superior forces, dividing 4 moves between their pawns on each turn.  Whoever controls the most pawns when the first player is wiped out is the winner.  Players may negotiate deals and form alliances.

Name: På nya äventyr med Pippi Långstrump
Description:
On new adventures with Pippi Longstocking.

Try to catch up with Pippi and her monkey Herr Nilsson on their adventures. If you are lucky to be in the same spot as Pippi you will receive 1 gold coin. The first who has 6 gold coins will win this game.

Childrens game Ages 5 and up.

Contents:

1 board game
1 dice
1 Pippi marker
1 Herr Nilsson marker
5 playing counter
30 gold coins.

Name: På nya hyss med Emil i Lönneberga
Description:
This is a game that is based on novel-writer Astrid Lindgren's most popular stories.

The game will take you on a journey on mischief, so hurry up, the one who will do the most mischief will win this game!!

Childrens game Ages 5 and up.

Contents:
1 Game board
1 dice
5 playing counter  
8 card with Emil-mischief
1 Emil Card

Name: ZombieTown 2: Road Rage
Description:
Zombietown 2 adds cars and hidden agendas to the mix of the ZombieTown universe.

Cars and keys are distributed one per household at random. Players must find a matching key to use the car.  Once the cars are in play they can be used to move quicker, run down zombies, or serve as makeshift barricades.

Hidden agendas are cards similar in size to the existing cards for the game.  Each agenda has two possible conditions worth additional victory points.  Players must choose one of them and reveal it when the conditions are met.  If the conditions are later lost, the player retains his VP.  The agendas on a card are related, so one might offer 5 points for having homes on two sides of the board and 10 for having homes on three sides.

Publisher's Page: http://www.twilightcreationsinc.com/zombietown/zombietown2.php

Expands

    ZombieTown

Name: Top Me
Description: Each player controls six cone-shaped "tops".  During their turn, players roll two six-sided dice and move one of their tops around the board forward or backward.  The object of the game is to capture all of your opponent's tops by landing on them before your opponents do.  Before the captures are complete, you can unload your captors into your home space.  The rules permit some areas on the board designated as safe zones and the option to trade captors with another player.

Name: Tooth and Claw
Description:
Tooth and Claw is a set of wargaming rules for hunters of prehistoric animals. One or more players can represent either stone age tribesmen or 19th Century sportsmen hunting after the biggest prey to roam the earth since the last Ice Age.

Weapon tables provide stats for pre-gunpowder weapons, muzzle-loading firearms, breech-loading rifles, and repeating guns.

Animal appearances are determined by encounter tables and their behavior, including attacks, are determined by the game system.

Animal stats include all the saber-tooth cats, prehistoric wolves and bears, mammoths, brontotheriums (rhinos), aurochs (oxen), giganthopithecus (gorillas), and giant birds.

There are 5 scenarios included in this 32 page full colour, self contained booklet.

Name: Wuzzles
Description:
Those delightfully mixed-up creatures, the Wuzzles, and their enchanted island of Wuz are just a wish away when you play this race game with the towering 3-D mountain.

The Wuzzles have been invited to a party, but unfortunately, their gifts have become as mixed up as the Wuzzles.  Bits and pieces of their presents have been scattered all over the gameboard.

Can you tunnel in and out of the 3-D mountain, put together a complete gift, avoid Croc and the Creepasaurs, and be the first to arrive at the party?

Name: BSO FOOTBALL
Description:
BSO FOOTBALL
THE HISTORY OF PRO FOOTBALL

For fans of Tabletop Sports games, and Football, here is one of, if not THE, best solitaire play football card/board game ever. BSO FOOTBALL provides its players with remarkable statistical accuracy in almost every category, in the most accessible, playable form in the game industry. There’s no trying to outguess yourself on offense or defense. You just call the play and roll the dice (which you provide). Player Cards, one for every offensive player on the team, the Defensive Ratings on the Team Charts, and the Results Tables do the rest.

Check the sample Player Cards, above, to see how players are rated.

The Team Charts provide the ratings/information for Defense, Interceptions, Clutch Play,  Fumbles, Penalties, and the full range of Returns and Kicking details. They also have Extra Information on Special and Unusual plays that team used. The Charts include Rushing, Pass Completion, Pass Gain and Return, Out-of-Bounds, Medium and Long Gains, Kickoff (including Onside Kicks), Punting (including Blocked Kicks), and a full range of Penalties.

The Game Clock is also extremely accurate, with each quarter using 180 “points”, each point equal to 5 seconds. A normal play would use 8 points, but an incomplete pass or Time Out only 1.

The first edition of BSO FOOTBALL brings you one of the greatest seasons in the History of Football, 1958, with the famous overtime Championship game between the Colts and the Giants. In the East the Giants and the Cleveland Browns, led by the great Jim Brown, had to use a playoff game to determine the winner, and the Steelers, led by the veteran Bobby Layne, were not that far behind. In the West, the Colts beat out both the Bears and Rams by one game.

Some of Pro Football’s greats are present:  Ollie Matson, Norm Van Brocklin, Johnny Unitas, Jon Arnett, Y. A. Tittle, and the first glimpses of Bart Starr, Jim Taylor, and Paul Hornung, all playing for one of the worst Green Bay teams ever (1-10-1)! And wait’ll you see the average yards per pass catch!  Steeler rookie, Jimmy Orr, led the league with 27.6, with many others not far behind.

For gamers who like to play entire seasons and revel in great statistical accuracy, BSO FOOTBALL is unbeatable. And, if you wish, there are special rules for face-to-face play, which use extended play calling (although, to be up front, that is not the game’s strong point).

player cards:  150
team cards”  12
others:  Charts, Schedules, Rules
cost:  $14 US; $15 Canada; $17 Pacific

Name: Safety First
Description:
Safety First: The Fun and Factual Game for Kids and Parents

This is a safety game for kids about how to stay safe when they're alone or in a difficult situation. The figures move around the board reaching places that represent school, the bus, home, the mall and other places a child might be. Children are asked questions about hypothetical situations - some social, some life-threatening - and asked to tell what they would do. Adult cards ask parents to answer questions about their own childhoods. When children are empowered by correct responses and adult reinforcement, their lives will be safer. Discussing these issues can help a kid to act smart, not scared if they find themselves in certain circumstances.

Name: Folio
Description:
Folio is an Icehouse-based  abstract strategy game for two players. The rules are simple, but the strategy can get mind-bending. It owes some rule ideas to the commercially available game Quarto (thus the name).

To play you require one stack of pyramids from each of four colours plus one extra from each colour (with only two of these being of the same size). You also need a chessboard or similar 8x8 grid.

Name: Flix
Description:
Flix was distributed as a single game containing three rule variants (Lucky Flix, Pay-Off Flix, and Tac-T-Flix).  The basic goal is to get 4 taxpayer men in a row on a three dimensional gameboard.  Specialized dice are used to limit the color and placement of pieces on the "Spaceboard".  In Tac-T-Flix, Burocrats, a second type of game piece, are introduced.

Contents:
One rules sheet says:

     54 flexible taxpayer men (in three colors for the different players
     24 Burocrat[sic] Men (8 of each color)
     3 special Flix dice
     12 Numbered Tokens


So there are 18 "taxpayer men" and 8 "burocrat[sic] men" in eaach of the three colors. The men are made from looks to be a drinking straw. The top on both is cut off at about a 60 degree angle to give a very pointy appearance. Presumably this is the end that you'd stick in first through the board holes. The bottoms of the taxpayer men are cut off straight across, however the burocrat[sic] men are notched into a "V" and are longer.

The numbered tokens are a card sheet with 12 very thin strips that are meant to be cut off. The strips have a number on them. The set is six 10's, three 25's, two 50's, and one 100. The idea is that when the strip is folded in half that the number is hidden when stuffed inside a "straw piece." The numbered tokens are only used in the  game Pay Off Flix by folding them in half and randomly splitting the 12 token between the two players.

Also see:
Qubic which is 4x4x4 tic-tac-toe

Name: Duel in the Sky
Description:
From the Box:

"They shall mount up with wings as eagles" (Isaiah 40:31)...and Duel in the Sky

This is a game of daring, strategy and chance.  Two eagles circle, stalk and pursue each other until one swoops to victory.

To hover, to dive, to climb, to soar is decided by chance and the cast of a die.  Direction and distance is decided by the strategy and daring of the player.

This is a 3-dimensional game that teaches in the simplest way:  depth perception over a 2-dimensional playing surface.

Contents:

A large playing surface (cloth board), a die, and two cube playing pieces.

Name: Thurn and Taxis: All Roads Lead to Rome
Description:
Second expansion for Thurn and Taxis - actually, 2 expansions in one.

"All roads lead to Rome"

1st expansion, "Audience": The players (clerics) try to arrive at the right time to be received in audience by the pope.

2nd expansion, "Offices of Honor": The postal staff still helps you - but now you can draw additional city cards, get victory points or even set a new house.

Expands:

    Thurn and Taxis


Contents:

    1 game board with various roads to Rome
    5 carriages in the colors of the countries (beige – Baiern; orange – Böhmen/Salzburg; etc.)
    26 office tiles
    20 audience tiles with 5 different clerymen in the four player colors
    4 summary tiles
    12 victory point chips
Families: Theme: Mail / Stamps / The Post Office

Name: Close and Destroy
Description:
Wargame that was included in TSR Games Magazine "Little Wars" in the early 1980's. This is an armor and tank game using TSR's standard wargame rules.

Expanded by:

     Close and Destroy II

Name: Town And Country
Description:
Many stories can be told and many adventures await in this clever sequencing game for young children.

As card after card is placed in a row, story pictures are created to talk about and share.  Players complete country or town scenes by matching the pictures, one after the other.  "Here's a farm with lots of animals! There's a truck carrying a big load".

Town and Country can be played alone or with friends, and no reading or number skills are required.

5 variations of play, including 2 cooperative versions.

Contents: 16 cards, Game Rules

Name: Black & White
Description:
Move and jump to make a 5 in-a-row or capture all the opponents pieces in this 2-player abstract game.

Equipment:


     a 5x5 board
     10 reversible pieces (like in Reversi/Othello)


Each player starts with 5 pieces - one plays white the other black. The game begins with each player dropping one piece per turn on an empty cell. After that, on each turn, each player must do one of the following two actions: 

     Use a friendly stone to jump (orthogonally or diagonally) over an enemy piece landing on the immediate empty cell and flipping the color of the jumped piece (black turns white, and vice versa). Jumps may be multiple - i.e. a series of jumps over one enemy piece each. 
     Move a friendly stone to an (orthogonal or diagonal) adjacent empty cell.


The player that either makes an (orthogonal or diagonal) 5 in-a-row or captures all the opponents pieces wins.

In the online version captures (potentially multiple) are forced, and the win is by 5 in-a-row or by forcing the opponent into a stalemate. The forced moves and stalemate is not mentioned in the original rather brief rules, while the win by complete capture is not mentioned in the online version.

Name: Ton: The Game of Professional Darts
Description:
Features:
The top 250 dart players from the WDF, the BDA (men) and the BDA (women) are rated for overall skill. You get 750 players in total.
Throw-by-throw action; separate scoring systems for ton+ scoring and doubling out. Out chart included.
100 action cards drive the game engine; a match can be played in a matter of minutes.
Score sheet allows for statistical tracking as you play.
Graphical dart board included; you may call your own shots for a player rather than use the out chart. Complete rulebook included.

Name: Fast 40: The Game of Pro Motocross
Description:
Features: 
Detailed lap-by-lap simulation of both Supercross & Supercross Lite. Quick qualifying process gets you into the evening heats in a few minutes.
All riders who participated in at least 3 events during last season are rated in overall skill. A large amount of unseeded riders are included to flesh out your qualifying field.
All tracks individually rated for speed and incidents.
Charts for recording lap times & cumulative times. Watch the race unfold lap-by-lap.
Drivers may crash, collide or suffer mechanical problems.

Name: Blade: The Game of Speed Skating
Description:
Features: 
All skaters who competed during the 2006 season (men & women) are included. They are each graded individually for all events in which they competed.
Simple phase system allows for quick play; game is broken down into 3 skating phases: Start, mid-race and finish. Skater's performance in these stages is then combined with a base score to obtain a final time
8 different events individually charted for time
Score sheet allows for statistical tracking as you score
Each skater rated for his/her propensity to fall; injuries and collisions may also occur. Skaters may also suffer a disqualification.

Name: All-Arounder: Women's Gymnastics Game
Description:
Features: 
Easy to play, an entire competition can be simulated in 1 session
All gymnasts who appeared in the 2006 season are rated in each of 4 events: Vault, Uneven Bars, Balance Beam and Floor Exercise
Individual scoring charts reflect the difficulty of each event, which when coupled with the athlete's individual rating for the event, give accurate scoring results
Point deduction system included. Athletes' scores will be adjusted due to flaws in their performance
Injury system allows for gymnasts who fall (either from an apparatus on during the floor exercise) to suffer injuries. Some may even have their careers ended by such an event!

Name: Limit: The Game of Pro Bass Fishing
Description:
Features: 
The top 104 elite anglers of 2006, along with hundreds of other regional anglers, are all included and rated in individual angling skill.
All major lakes on the pro bass tour included and charted for catching frequency and weight base
Fact action cards drive the angling; obtain results for each angler quickly; "phase" system splits the fishing day into 5 segments.
Full featured events chart; experience all the oddities, fish patterns and angler behavior just as you would in real life
Optional practice session system allow anglers to get the feel of the lake; a good practice may raise their odds. Weigh-in system in which penalties may occur at weigh-in Weather system also affects the angling performance. Anglers may even catch foreign objects or suffer boating mishaps!

Name: Podium: The Game of Formula 1 Racing
Description:
Features:
Lap by lap simulation of the 2006 season
All drivers who participated in the 2006 season are included. Each is rated in overall driving ability, retirement frequency, types of retirements, pit frequency and pit crew ability.
Each circuit is individually charted to give realistic lap times.
Circuits are also rated for incident frequency
Cumulative time sheet lets you track each drivers' lap-by-lap performance; position chart lets you see at a glance how the field is progressing as the race unfolds.

Name: Track Shot: The Demolition Derby Game
Description:
Features:
Features more than 500 drivers, each rated in overall performance.
All play derived from 100 "action cards": over 100 cars to choose from.
Track conditions, pre-derby inspections, officiating style all play a part in the outcome.
Fires, the pit crew, hangups, stalls, loose car parts on the track, and many more events/components of a derby are all simulated.
Run heats, a consolation and a main event. 3 different car classes to choose from: Compact, Full-Size ('77 & newer) and Old Iron. Cars take damage just like in a real demo. Keep score as you run the events.

Name: Rommel: The Campaign for North Africa
Description:
Rommel: The Campaign for North Africa by Loren F. Sperry, self published.

1 22" x 34" map of the campaign area from El Agheila to just east of El Alamein. Turn scale is 3 turns to the month from Sept 1940 to Dec 1942. 252 1/2 counters (very thin perforated cardboard) represent the divisions, regiments, brigades and strength breakdown counters.

Game play is a simple move then fight. Supply is a bit tougher in that all units must be with 5 hexes of a supply unit, which are expended for combat.

There are some chrome rules, minefields, fortifications, recon units.

Name: Towers&Bridges
Description:
GAME SUMMARY:
Towers&Bridges is a board game for two players. It combines traditional elements of chess —such as a squared board— with original pieces and movements. The game symbolizes a battle between two feudal lords: the White Lord and the Black Lord. Each one leads an army composed by attack towers and portable bridges.
The principal aim of attack towers is to capture enemy castles. But these are surrounded by deep moats. Portable bridges are used to cover those moats. In this way, towers can cross moats; and thus, they can take castles… but only if the tower is as high as the castle. Most attack towers are initially smaller than most castles. However, they can get bigger by capturing an enemy tower. When this happens, the stages of the defeated tower are added to the winning one. So, winning attack towers become higher and higher. In the end, they may even match the highest castle: that is, the enemy lord’s one.
During the combat, both contenders may be helped by mercenaries and flying creatures. But these are jailed in strong citadels, so first of all, attack towers must free them. Once they have been liberated, mercenaries can blow enemy bridges up; and winged creatures can transport their lord by air, crossing even moats not covered by bridges.
The main purpose in the game is to trap the opponent’s feudal lord, who takes shelter in the highest castle. The player who gets this objective wins.

NOTES:
-This information was submitted by the publisher.
-The game has been published in English and Spanish.
-The game has been published as a book. Besides the rules and a game example, the book contains the cut-out board and pieces, both in duplicate.
-Towers&Bridges in English is available at: http://www.lulu.com/content/2687006
-In Spanish at: http://www.lulu.com/content/1354342

Name: Round Trip
Description: This is a game created as an individual class project , this is my first stab at designing my own game. You start off with four pieces per player, you move around the circular game board with color coordinated cards to the spaces on the board. Your objective is to get all four of your pieces back to the starting position the fastest but beware your opponents because they can land on an occupied space of yours and send you back to the beginning.

Name: FIFA World Cup Chess
Description: This game is very similar to chess. The same pieces are used and their movement is almost identical. The objective of the game is to score goals using your pieces. You must score on the goalie (king) until 3 points are acquired by one team.

Name: Trice
Description:
Trice is a game for 3 players that uses Icehouse pieces and a small, triangular gameboard. This game also uses dice. A set of 3 four-sided dice is recommended; however, if these are unavailable, the game can also be played with a pair of regular six-sided dice.

The object of the game is to occupy all of the spaces on the board that contain a specific mystic symbol. The 3 symbols are the sun, the moon, and the star. For each of these symbols, there are 5 spaces on the board that must be occupied in order to win. Two of these spaces contain only the one symbol, two are shared with one other symbol (these are called Bi-Spaces), and the final space contains all 3 symbols. (This space is the center space on the board, and it is called the Tri-Space.)

The complete rules are available at Wunderland.com.

Name: The Martian Gathering
Description:
The Martian Gathering brings two armies of Icehouse pyramids with different powers to the battlefield, where their commanders apply their leadership and magical skills through Magic cards to achieve victory.

You need Icehouse pieces for the five colours of Magic: The Gathering plus a clear set if you want to use colourless spells. The game plays fine with the basic set and fewer card colors. Each player also needs 20 Magic cards which fit their anticipated army.

Knowledge of the Magic: the Gathering rules is assumed.

Rules Link

Name: Martian Race
Description:
The object of Martian Race is to be the first player to get all of the Martians from your family from your Home to the Government Center (to sign up for the program and get supply vouchers), the Supply Depot (to get, well, supplies), and then to the Launch Pad (to head off into space and down in history).

You will need one Icehouse-stash per player as well as two six-sided dice and a chess-board.

The complete rules are available online.

Name: Mandala
Description: Mandala is a deceptively simple game of set collection played on a randomly-created path of Icehouse pieces. It is an adaptation of Knizia's Tutankhamen for 5 rainbow stashes of Looney Pyramids. Players place their pawns at the outside of the spiral of pyramids and collect pyramids as they move toward the center. They score points for having the majority in any particular "set" (group of 5 identical pyramids, e.g. 5 medium yellow pyramids). The player with the most points when all players (except one) have reached the center is the winner.

Name: Edges
Description:
Edges is an abstract strategy game of placement for Icehouse-pyramids, played on the 31 edges (not squares or points) of a three by four rectangular grid representing a canal network.

Its rules are here: http://icehousegames.org/wiki/index.php?title=Edges

Name: Martian Life
Description:
An Icehouse game based on Conway's Game of Life. It requires one stash of pyramids per player and one chess-board. Each turn, a player places a small onto an empty space, or grows one of their existing pieces (small to medium, or medium to large). Then dead pieces are removed simultaneously from the entire board. As in Conway's Game of Life, a piece's survival depends on the number of adjacent neighbors: smalls need 1-3 neighbors, mediums need 3-5 neighbors, and larges need 5-7 neighbors to survive.

Rules Link

Name: Martian Frisby
Description:
Martian Frisby is an Icehouse game. It is played using nestable Icehouse game pieces, a chessboard, and dice.

Like Mrs. Frisby, you must move your nest to safety. And like a Martian, you must obey the Laws of the Pyramids.

You start with six pieces nested at one end of a chessboard. Roll the dice, and try to move all your pieces to the other end of the board. Along the way, you may nest pieces, but you may never stack them.

Rules Link

Name: Igloo
Description:
Igloo is a turn-based Icehouse game for 2 players (or 2 teams) which can be played on any flat, stable surface. The game uses a standard set of Icehouse pieces and is set up in a similar manner, with the pieces starting out in stash zones that are not part of the playing field. Each player plays a single piece during each turn. The game ends after all pieces have been played.

Each player controls 2 sets of pyramids. However, only one set of pyramids will be worth points at the end of the game. The other set are decoys. Trying to figure out which is which, from the player's style of play and skill at bluffing, adds a level of intrigue to the game.

The complete rules are available at Wunderland.com.

Name: Cross Board Hockey
Description:
From www.crossboardlogic.com:

Cross-Board Hockey is a game of strategy similar to the popular game of soccer or hockey.

The game is played by two players each having his (or her) own team of 14 pieces. The player who is first to place one of his pieces on the net field belonging to the opposing player wins the game.

Name: Cosmos
Description:
A game involving luck, good timing and knowing the odds.

The game is a push your luck game for up to four players. Each turn a player rolls five dice and tries to advance along a linear track which marks the players score. To win, players must land on the "1200 points" space exactly.

Four dice are numbered 1-5 and 10, and the fifth is a "wild" dice, which has at least one side labeled "wild." Points are scored for rolling 5's and 10's, and also for rolling straights, three of a kind etc., in a similar manner to Yahtzee. After rolling players have the option of holding scoring dice (5's or 10's) or rolling.

However if a non-scoring combination is rolled, players lose points rolled in the current round.

The score track also features way stations, which earn the players "Opportunity points."

Name: Gurgitate!: the Game of Competitive Eating
Description:
Features:
The top pro eaters from the past 3 seasons are individually carded and rated.
Each eater is rated in each different event for which he or she participated
Fast and accurate results. The average 8-10 minute contest can be reproduced in around 30 minutes.
17 different foods each individually charted. Hot Dogs, Burgers, Meatballs, Ribs, Jalapenos, and many more foods await!
100 ready-to-print action cards included
Custom events system accounts for all of the unusual happenings in an eating competition; DQ's, penalties, and more are all here!

Name: Trivial Pursuit: Édition Cinéma
Description:
250 extra cards to be used with any Trivial Pursuit basic game.
The new cards feature 1500 questions on cinema -- mostly French pictures, but also international features.

Name: Queen Bee's Color and Shape Party!
Description:
Learn about colors and shapes while racing to be the first guest at the Queen's party!

Teach children to identify six basic colors and five basic shapes with this delightful game you can play three ways. Use just the color cards, just the shape cards, or both! Students will also learn how to follow rules and take turns.

Includes game board, 36 cards, 4 markers, directions, and teaching suggestions. Supports NAEYC standards.

Name: Het Mega Mindy Time Bordspel
Description:
Mega Mindy is a "world Famous" Flemish (Belgian) character, kind of wonderwoman, for the kids.
She has her own TV series, puzzles, pyama's (pajamas???) and .. her first game.

This is a racing game between you, as Mega Mindy, and a crook, a race to get to the money.  By rolling the dice, you have to turn yourself into Mega Mindy, giving you special powers (faster/bigger moves) to get hold of the money first.

Good luck.

Name: Axis & Allies Miniatures Expanded Rules
Description:
Expanded rules book, with additional rules beyond those included in the Advanced Rulebook (found in starter sets).

New rules include Formations, Single-Nation Armies, Special Units, Overwatch Fire, Enfilade Fire, and Grazing Fire, plus modified rules for Anti-Aircraft Fire and Defensive Fire.

New maps are also included, compatible with the maps from the 1939-1945 and later editions.

Expands:

    Axis & Allies Miniatures

Name: Salt Lake City on Board
Description: Salt Lake City on Board is a Monopoly clone based on the capital of Utah. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Ouelessebougou-Utah Alliance. (Jail is replaced with The Utah Symphony and Opera. Is classical music really as bad as prison?)

Name: Park City On Board
Description: Park City on Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city of Park City UT. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game benefit the Summit County Friends of Animals.

Name: Car Race
Description:
A rip-roaring car race for 2-4 professional drivers. Ages 5 and up.

It's an easy game of car racing based in a simple roll and move mechanic. The circuit are made up with wood sticks placed in circle.

To move, the player rolls the die, if on the die appears one, two or three dots then he moves the car accordingly over one, two or three sticks. It the die shows a jerry can the player get a turbo counter but can not move. In a later turn the player can use the turbo counter to double the number of dots appearing on the die.

Name: Oakville On Board
Description: Oakville On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Ontario, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit Wellspring, the Salvation Army Lighthouse, and the Children’s Miracle Network.

Name: Newfoundland and Labrador On Board
Description: Newfoundland and Labrador On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Canadian Province. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Boys & Girls Clubs of Newfoundland and Labrador .

Name: Naperville On Board
Description: Naperville On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Illinois. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Edward Hospital Foundation.

Name: Minnesota On Board
Description: Minnesota On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the US state of Minnesota. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit Bolder Options.

Name: Madison on Board
Description: Madison On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Wisconsin. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the The Chris Farley Foundation.

Name: Kitchener Waterloo On Board
Description: Kitchener Waterloo On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the cities in Ontario, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Centre In The Square's School Program and Community Ticket Program.

Name: Kansas City On Board
Description: Kansas City On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Missouri. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Académie Lafayette and the YMCA of Greater Kansas City.

Name: Kelowna On Board
Description: Kelowna On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in British Columbia, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Junior Achievement of British Columbia - Okanagan.

Name: Joliet On Board
Description: Joliet On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Illinois city. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Joliet Region Chamber of Commerce.

Name: Kingston On Board
Description: Kingston On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Ontario, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Queen's Football Club and Children's Wish Foundation.

Name: Janesville On Board
Description: Janesville On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Wisconsin city. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Boys & Girls Club of Janesville.

Name: Hamilton On Board
Description: Hamilton On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Ontario, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit Family Services of Hamilton.

Name: Halifax On Board
Description: Halifax On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Nova Scotia, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Bryony House – A Shelter for Battered Women.

Name: Greeley On Board
Description: Greeley On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Colorado city. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Boys & Girls Club of Weld County.

Name: Greater Memphis On Board
Description: Greater Memphis On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Tennessee city. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Children of Youth Villages.

Name: Greater Saint John On Board
Description: Greater Saint John On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in New Brunswick, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit The Resource Center for Youth in Greater Saint John Inc.

Name: Greater Bozeman On Board
Description: Greater Bozeman On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Montana City. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Headwaters Academy.

Name: Galveston On Board
Description: Galveston On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Texas city. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Galveston Bay Foundation.

Name: Fredericton On Board
Description: Fredericton On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in New Brunswick, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Chimo Helpline Inc.

Name: Fort Worth On Board
Description: Fort Worth On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Texas city. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the YWCA Forth Worth & Tarrant County.

Name: Duluth On Board
Description: Duluth On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Minnesota city. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Duluth Children's Museum.

Name: Dubuque on Board
Description: Dubuque On Board  is a Monopoly clone based on the Iowa city. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Dubuque Sertoma Club.

Name: Fort Wayne On Board
Description: Fort Wayne On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Indiana city. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit Leadership Fort Wayne Inc.

Name: Denver On Board
Description: Denver On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the Colorado City. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Denver Safe House.

Name: Colorado On Board
Description: Colorado On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the US State. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Young Audiences of Colorado.

Name: Cape Breton On Board
Description: Cape Breton On Board is a Monopoly clone based on the city in Nova Scotia, Canada. Board squares are replaced with landmarks and businesses from the area. Proceeds from the game go to benefit the Junior Achievement of Nova Scotia.
